slides.title: PowerPoint with Codex
slides.subtitle: Generate branded decks with the Worldline template

slides.title: What This Shows
bullets: Turn a prompt into a structured slide plan (JSON)
Generate a branded PPTX from the JSON spec
Iterate quickly by editing the JSON and re-generating
Optionally export slide images for visual QA (PNG/JPG)

slides.title: Prerequisites
bullets: Codex with the `pptx-generator` skill installed
Python + `python-pptx` available in the environment
A corporate template (`assets/worldline-template.pptx` or `--template <path>`)
A place to save outputs (e.g. `dist/`)
Optional: PowerPoint (Windows) or LibreOffice for snapshots

slides.title: Workflow Overview
slides.left:
1) Ask Codex
• Topic + audience + slide count
• Include branding requirement

2) Review JSON
• Titles, bullets, structure
• Split dense slides

3) Generate PPTX
• Run generator with template

slides.title: Prompt Pattern (What to Tell Codex)
bullets: Audience + goal (e.g., exec update, training, customer pitch)
Desired length (e.g., 8–12 slides) and level of detail
Key messages and what must be included / excluded
Branding requirement: use Worldline template
Tone: concise titles, 3–6 bullets per slide, avoid walls of text

slides.title: Example Codex Request
slides.left:
In Codex

`$pptx-generator`
Generate a Worldline-branded deck on:
“How to generate a PowerPoint with Codex”

Constraints
• 10 slides max
• Practical, step-by-step
• Include commands + file locations
slides.right:
Codex should produce

• A slide outline (titles + bullets)
• A JSON config in `assets/`
• A generated `.pptx` in `dist/`

Optional
• Slide snapshots for quick visual review

slides.title: Generate with the Worldline Template
bullets: Command (recommended): `python3 pptx-generator/scripts/generate_pptx.py --config pptx-generator/assets/deck.json --output dist/deck.pptx --theme template --qa`
To use a different template: add `--template /path/to/template.pptx`
WSL tip: `wslpath -u "C:\\path\\to\\template.pptx"` converts Windows → WSL paths
Debug template layouts: add `--list-layouts`
Force a layout per slide: set `template_layout` or `template_layout_index` in JSON

slides.title: Edit the JSON (Fast Iteration)
bullets: Keep slide titles short and assertive (1 line)
Prefer multiple concise slides over one dense slide
Use `two-column` for comparisons and workflows
Use `\n` (or literal `\\n`) to create line breaks inside `left`/`right` text
Regenerate after every change to validate layout + flow

slides.title: Visual QA (Snapshots)
bullets: Simplest: add `--qa` to auto-split dense slides after generation
Generate + snapshot: add `--snapshots-dir dist/deck-slides --snapshots-format png --snapshots-gallery`
Or export later: `python3 pptx-generator/scripts/export_slides.py --pptx dist/deck.pptx --outdir dist/deck-slides --format png --gallery`
Use `--method powerpoint` (best) or `--method libreoffice` (Linux/WSL)
Scan for: text overflow, tiny fonts, awkward spacing, low contrast
Fix JSON → regenerate → re-snapshot until it reads cleanly

slides.title: Readability Checklist
slides.left:
Content
• 1 idea per slide
• Parallel bullet structure
• Remove filler words
• Use concrete examples
• End with an action
slides.right:
Design
• Aim for 28+ pt body text
• ≤ 5 bullets per slide
• Prefer whitespace over density
• Use consistent capitalization
• Keep commands short

slides.title: Common Fixes
bullets: Too much text → split into 2 slides or convert to `two-column`
Text overflow → shorten bullets (or reduce to 3–4 bullets)
Template layout looks wrong → set `template_layout_index` on that slide
Need visuals → add an `image` slide (diagram / screenshot)
Inconsistent style → standardize titles, bullets, and punctuation

slides.title: Ship It
slides.subtitle: The JSON is your source of truth — keep it versioned
